newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dollar largely immune to easing - Aust analyst.
newsitem.headline: NZ dollar largely immune to easing - Aust analyst.

text.p: Any easing in New Zealand monetary conditions is unlikely to have a significant negative impact on the high-flying kiwi dollar, an Australian analyst said on Tuesday.

Steve Shuster, Citibank Australia's head of foreign exchange, told Reuters Financial Television that while it seemed likely the Reserve Bank would ease policy, it was questionable whether this would have a significantly downward impact on the currency.
"The export sector is hurting. So the RBNZ is probably in a position where it can ease. But the question is whether this would actually affect the spot market.
"Should we get a one percent easing in the December monetary policy statement, we'll still have short rates at nine percent. That's still attractive."
The currency touched 71.46 U.S. cents in early Tuesday trade and hit 68.08 on the Trade Weighted Index, its highest levels since mid-1988.
Shuster said he did not think the RBNZ would have to release a statement before December to cool the market.

"For the time being, we've probably seen the larger extent of the kiwi's upward move. And I think the RBNZ feels that as well, so there's probably no panic on their behalf. We'll now just wait and see what unfolds on the political front."
Shuster said while yield-driven buying would continue, this would be offset by profit-taking as investors, faced with a heavy funding cost, sold Kiwi bonds.
He forecast a short-term range of 70.00 to 72.00 U.S. cents for the kiwi, with the currency unlikely to breach 69.80 on the downside.
Clifford Bennett, technical analyst at Creative Currencies in Sydney, told RFTV that the kiwi's breach of resistance at 71.25 U.S. cents had set the currency up for a try at 72 cents.
"The nature of the price action suggests that the currency hasn't expired - there's some some energy there," he said.
